content: That happens because the account is IMAP and each time Thunderbird issues a save, a new copy is created. To avoid that, set your drafts folder to Local Folders instead.
creator: davidsk

content:
I generally recommend that, when setting up a second PC, to just copy the working setup from the first PC.

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, started once and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This WILL prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it 
#   start thunderbird and all should be there

The second PC should be equal or NEWER than the first PC. That is, copying to a newer version is good, copying to an older version is not.
creator: davidsk

content:
I don't completely understand your description, but as far as I know, the "Send Later" button is only available when you are in offline mode. If you are online, that button is replaced by the "Send" button. Check the menu option <File | Offline> and see of "Work offline" is checked.

This also might happen if you lose network connectivity.
creator: rednoise

content: have you set 'server settings' to request authentication? That is a common issue.

content: Please provide more detail so that you get useful information. Is this a POP account? I presume so, since you state that the account has been shut down. My inference is that you want to save the messages elsewhere from account, such as in Local Folders. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content:
That sounds unusual. If the profile worked in another thunderbird, then it will work here. My guess is there is a difference in version numbers and there may be a compatibility.ini file that could be deleted. Your current problem is that you moved the default profile, so when thunderbird tries to start, it's not there. I would place the thunderbird folder back in place and try again. If you get an error message, please post it. here are my normal steps:

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, started once and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This WILL prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it 
#   start thunderbird and all should be there

HOWEVER

If your backup is just the profile itself, then do this:

  1. install thunderbird on new pc, downloaded from thunderbird.net
  2. in receiving PC, click help>troubleshootinginformation
  3. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  4. exit thunderbird
  5. now, paste contents of exported profile, overlaying contents of profile.
  6. if there is a compatibility.ini file, delete it
  7. restart thunderbird
creator: davidsk

content: This has been an ongoing problem for many years. I've complained about it here and so have others. It seems to be some undesirable interaction between Google Calendar, Google Contacts, and Thunderbird. Calendar notifications can be turned off in Thunderbird, but that takes away much of the utility of the calendar in the first place. As far as I know there is no definitive explanation, and no real solution. But if somebody has one, I'm all ears.
creator: rednoise

content: Yeah, I may just end up turning off notifications In Thunderbird. I get them on my phone anyway.
creator: spartanhooah
